holdings.text: The 10 Malis are workmen under section 2(s) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 as adopted by the U.P. Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: That-is why we think that the Labour Appellate Tribunal was right in coming to the conclusion that Malis are workmen under the Act. Before we part with this point, we would like to add that industrial adjudication appears consistently to have taken the view that Malis looking after the gardens attached to the bungalows occupied by officers of any industrial concern are workmen under s. 2(s).

holdings.reasoning_summary: Malis engaged in incidental operations (maintaining officers' bungalow gardens as amenity) connected to main industry (spinning/weaving); rejects literal 'employed in industry'; follows industrial adjudication precedents (Bhikari, Upper India Chini); analogies to clerks, sweepers, bus drivers.

holdings.text: Malis are 'industrial employees' within the meaning of G.O. No. 3754 LL XVIII-894 L-1948 and entitled to dear food allowance under paragraph 3 thereof.

anchor.surface_text: That is the view -taken by the Labour Appellate Tribunal and, in our opinion, that view is obviously right. If that be so, the validity of the order passed by the Labour Appellate Tribunal awarding the respondents claim for dear food allowance under paragraph 3 of the G.O. cannot be questioned.

holdings.reasoning_summary: G.O. issued under s.3(b),(g) U.P. Act binds all 'workmen' under s.2 (i.e., IDA s.2(s)); 'industrial employees' co-extensive with 'workmen', not narrower Factories Act 'worker'; distinguishes Suti Mill as erroneous.

holdings.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal rightly awarded leave with wages to Malis on lines of s.79 Factories Act on grounds of social justice, despite statutes inapplicable.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, satisfied that there is no substance in the grievance made by Mr. Pathak that the Labour Appellate Tribunal should not have granted the demand of the respondents for leave on grounds of fair-play and social justice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Claim in general terms, not limited to specific statutes; social justice integral to industrial adjudication (Crown Aluminium, Gold Mines); pragmatic balancing for harmony, national economy; rejects irrelevance argument (distinguishes JK Iron, Muir Mills).

holdings.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal's decision on Badri's dismissal (workman status, unjustified dismissal, reinstatement with full wages) correct and undisputed.

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal, Mr. Pathak has not disputed the correctness or propriety of the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal in regard to the claim made by the respondents in respect of Badris dismissal. So, that part of the dispute need not detain us in the present appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant conceded; upholds lower tribunals' findings on merits.

holdings.text: Civil Appeal No. 481 of 1962 dismissed with costs; Civil Appeal No. 480 of 1962 dismissed as not pressed.

anchor.surface_text: The result is, Civil Appeal No. 481/1962 fails and is dismissed with costs. Civil Appeal No. 480 of 1962 has not been pressed and is, therefore, dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Merits resolved against appellant; CA 480 unnecessary as CA 481 covers dispute.

anchor.surface_text: In Shri Bhikari, Kanpur v. Messrs. Cooper Allen Co., Kanpur,  1  the Labour Appellate Tribunal while dealing with the case of Bhikari who was engaged as a gardener by the Company and was on the pay-roll of the Company observed that the Tribunal failed to see why he is number to be regarded as a workman within the meaning of s. 2  s  of the Industrial Disputes Act which  1  1952 L. A. C. 298.

precedents.case_name: Shri Bhikari Kanpur v. Messrs Cooper Allen Co Kanpur
precedents.cited_proposition: gardener engaged by company and on pay-roll is workman under s. 2(s) of Industrial Disputes Act
precedents.cited_holding: Tribunal failed to see why he is not to be regarded as a workman

anchor.surface_text: The same view was taken by the Labour Appellate Tribunal in the case of The Upper India Chini Mazdoor Union v. The Upper India Sugar Mills  1 . Dealing, with the case of Rati Rama Who was engaged as a Mali, the Tribunal rejected the employers companytention that the said Mali was a domestic servant and observed that merely because the Company chooses to put Rati Ram on the work of a gardener with the Managing Director which the A Company is admittedly required to provide for and pay for, it does number follow that Rati Ram became a domestic servant. It is remarkable that both these decisions which are directly in point, were under s. 2 of the Act with which we are companycerned. 1 1953 L. C. 870.

precedents.case_name: The Upper India Chini Mazdoor Union v. The Upper India Sugar Mills
precedents.cited_proposition: Mali engaged as gardener for Managing Director is not domestic servant but workman under s. 2 of the Act
precedents.cited_holding: merely because the Company chooses to put Rati Ram on the work of a gardener with the Managing Director... it does not follow that Rati Ram became a domestic servant

anchor.surface_text: It is true that in The Suti Mill Mazdoor Sabha Kanpur v. Messrs. The British Indian Corporation Ltd. Kanpur  1 , the Labour Appellate Tribunal appears to have taken the view that the expression industrial employees is limited to the class of employees who are employed directly or indirectly for the purpose of manufacturing process carried on by the factory. In companying to this companyclusion, the Labour Appellate Tribunal numbericed the fact that the expression industrial employees had number been defined, but it was disposed to drive assistance from the definition of the word worker in the Factories Act in determining the scope of the expression industrial employees. No doubt, it was urged before the Tribunal that expression industrial employees should be understood in the same companyprehensive sense as the word industry as defined in the industrial Disputes Act, but this companytention was rejected by the Tribunal. It seems to us that the Tribunal was in error in limiting the, scope of  1 1956 L.A.C. 549 the expression.

precedents.case_name: The Suti Mill Mazdoor Sabha Kanpur v. Messrs The British Indian Corporation Ltd Kanpur
precedents.cited_proposition: industrial employees limited to class employed directly or indirectly for manufacturing process, by reference to Factories Act definition of worker

anchor.surface_text: ...he referred us to the observations made by this Court on some occasions that the-considerations of social justice were number only irrelevant but untenable vide J.K. anchor.surface_text: The development of industrial law during the last decade and several decisions of this Court in dealing with industrial matters have emphasised the relevance, validity and significance of the doctrine of social justice, vide Messrs. Crown Aluminum Works v. Their Workmen,  s  and The State of Mysore v. The Workers of Gold Mines  4  Indeed the companycept of social justice has number become such an integral part of industrial law that it would be idle for any party to suggest that industrial adjudication can or should ignore the claims of social justice in dealing with industrial disputes.  3 1958S.C.R. 651.

precedents.case_name: Messrs Crown Aluminum Works v Their Workmen

anchor.surface_text: That-is why we think that the Labour Appellate Tribunal was right in coming to the conclusion that Malis are workmen under the Act. Before we part with this point, we would like to add that industrial adjudication appears consistently to have taken the view that Malis looking after the gardens attached to the bungalows occupied by officers of any industrial concern are workmen under s. 2(s).
The result is, Civil Appeal No. 481/1962 fails and is dismissed with costs. Civil Appeal No. 480 of 1962 has not been pressed and is, therefore, dismissed.
